sentence.text: ï»¿The second affected fetus was delivered 10 years later.

Ultrasound examination at 28 weeks of gestation demonstrated findings similar to those observed in the prior affected pregnancy, with micromelia, thoracic dystrophy, cystic hygroma, and polyhydramnios.
At 34.3 weeks gestation, the patient was admitted in spontaneous labor.
This infant was also born by spontaneous vaginal delivery, and lived for approximately 60 min.
Measurements at autopsy included 28.5 cm crown-to-heel length, 24.5 cm crown-to-rump length, 1,737 g body weight, and 34.2 cm head circumference.
Radiographic, external, and microscopic examinations showed findings identical to those of the prior affected infant (Figs. 1B, 2 and 3).

Radiographic examination of the second fetus shows typical features of ACG2 including proportionately large skull, severe micromelia, flat acetabular roofs, wide sacrosciatic notches, tiny thorax, and minimal vertebral body ossification.

Histologic exam of the humerus shows an abnormal costochondral junction lacking the typical ossification zone, with haphazard arrangement of enlarged resting zone chondrocytes within stellate-shaped lacunae (inset).
